      2. Choice of latent distribution.

Neural Sampling from Boltzmann Densities:
Fisher-Rao Curves in the Wasserstein Geometry

Jannis Chemseddine, Christian Wald, Richard Duong, Gabriele Steidl
Institute of Mathematics
TU Berlin
StraÃŸe des 17. Juni 136 Berlin, Germany
Correspondence to: chemseddine@math.tu-berlin.de
Abstract

We deal with the task of sampling from an unnormalized Boltzmann density ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by learning a Boltzmann curve given by energies ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT starting in a simple density ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. First, we examine conditions under which Fisher-Rao flows are absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein geometry. Second, we address specific interpolations ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the learning of the related density/velocity pairs (Ït,vt)subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡(\rho_{t},v_{t})( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). It was numerically observed that the linear interpolation, which requires only a parametrization of the velocity field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, suffers from a â€teleportation-of-massâ€ issue. Using tools from the Wasserstein geometry, we give an analytical example, where we can precisely measure the explosion of the velocity field. Inspired by MÃ¡tÃ© and Fleuret, who parametrize both ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we propose an interpolation which parametrizes only ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fixes an appropriate vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This corresponds to the Wasserstein gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence related to Langevin dynamics. We demonstrate by numerical examples that our model provides a well-behaved flow field which successfully solves the above sampling task.

1 Introduction

In this paper, we consider the problem of sampling from a Boltzmann density ÏD=eâˆ’fD/ZDsubscriptğœŒğ·superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ·subscriptğ‘ğ·\rho_{D}=e^{-f_{D}}/Z_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with unknown normalizing constant ZDsubscriptğ‘ğ·Z_{D}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our approach is in the spirit of recent developments in generative modelling and aims to construct a curve Ït=eâˆ’ft/ZtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\rho_{t}=e^{-f_{t}}/Z_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT interpolating between a simple density ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the target ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If such curve admits a velocity field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there exists a solution Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† of

âˆ‚tÏ†t=vtâ¢(Ï†t),Ï†0=Idwhere(Ï†t)â™¯â¢(ÏZâ¢dâ¢x)=Ïtâ¢dâ¢x,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‘0Idwheresubscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡â™¯subscriptğœŒğ‘dğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘¡dğ‘¥\partial_{t}\varphi_{t}=v_{t}(\varphi_{t}),\quad\varphi_{0}=\mathrm{Id}\quad% \text{where}\quad(\varphi_{t})_{\sharp}(\rho_{Z}\mathrm{d}x)=\rho_{t}\mathrm{d% }x,âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Id where ( italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â™¯ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x ) = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x , (1)

then we can use Ï†1subscriptğœ‘1\varphi_{1}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to sample from ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An important question is, whether for a given family of functions ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such velocity fields exists. While, for a fixed time tğ‘¡titalic_t, the existence of such velocity fields is well established, see e.g. Laugesen etÂ al. (2014), global existence with integrability of v:[0,1]Ã—â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘£â†’01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„v:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_v : [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R in time and space is addressed in this paper. This is directly related to the question whether a large class of Fisher-Rao curves ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein geometry, and in particular, fulfills a continuity equation. This can be reduced to finding solutions of a certain family of PDEs. With the appropriate Hilbert spaces at hand, we show the existence of the solutions of these PDEs and the existence of an integrable velocity field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in time and space which admits moreover a minimality property of â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(â„d,Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Determining Ï†1subscriptğœ‘1\varphi_{1}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT requires both finding a curve ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the associated vector field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One way is to choose a curve interpolating between fZsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘f_{Z}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fDsubscriptğ‘“ğ·f_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT first and then to learn the velocity field. For the linear interpolation ft=(1âˆ’t)â¢fZ+tâ¢fDsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·f_{t}=(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using above considerations, we show that there indeed exists an integrable velocity field implying the absolute continuity of the curve in the Wasserstein space. Yet, it was numerically shown that the corresponding velocity field is often badly behaved as noted in (MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret, 2023, Figure 4 and 6). We highlight by an analytic example the bad regularity of this flow and show in particular that its velocity field may have an exploding norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(â„d,Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Another approach, recently proposed by MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023), considers ft=(1âˆ’t)â¢fZ+tâ¢fD+tâ¢(1âˆ’t)â¢Ïˆtsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}=(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with unknown Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ and learns (Ïˆt,vt)subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡(\psi_{t},v_{t})( italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) simultaneously. Henceforth, we refer to this method as the â€learned interpolationâ€. However, it is theoretically unclear whether the learned curve is well-behaved or the velocity field is optimal with respect to the above norm. As an alternative approach, we propose instead to deal directly with a well-behaved and mathematically accessible curve on [0,T]0ğ‘‡[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] and consider the parameterization ft=Tâˆ’tTâ¢fD+tâ¢Ïˆtsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}=\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fixing the velocity field as vtâ‰”âˆ‡(ftâˆ’fZ)â‰”subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla(f_{t}-f_{Z})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‡ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) we only have to learn Ïˆtsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡\psi_{t}italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting PDE is the well-known Fokker-Planck equation related to Langevin dynamics which has a solution with Boltzmann densities ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if, e.g., ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Gaussian. Then, the corresponding SDE is the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process. Here, the backward ODE of (1) must be applied for sampling. Finally, we learn the networks for the above three cases and demonstrate by numerical examples the effectiveness of our approach.

Contributions.

  1. 1.

    We prove for the first time that under mild conditions every reasonable curve of Boltzmann densities is an absolutely continuous Wasserstein curve, see Theorems 1 and 2.

  2. 2.

    We verify by an analytic example that the velocity field corresponding to the linear interpolation can admit an exploding norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(â„d,Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, leading to a â€non-smoothâ€ particle transport.

  3. 3.

    We propose to learn a curve using the parameterization ft=Tâˆ’tTâ¢fD+tâ¢Ïˆtsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}=\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we call â€gradient flow interpolationâ€ by the following reason. With an appropriate velocity field which can be computed directly from ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this resembles the Wasserstein gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence with fixed second argument ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This curve can be also described as the Fokker-Planck equation of a Langevin SDE.

  4. 4.

    We learn the networks for the linear, learned and gradient flow interpolations and demonstrate the performance of these three methods on certain sampling problems.

Related Work.

Classical approaches for sampling from an unnormalized density are based on the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, see Gilks etÂ al. (1995), including variants as the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMM) in Hoffman & Gelman (2014) or the Metropolis Adjusted Langevin Algorithm (MALA) in Girolami & Calderhead (2011). Arising problems with the correct distribution of mass among different modes lead to the use of importance sampling Neal (2001) and sequential Monte Carlo samplers Moral etÂ al. (2006).
Newer approaches include the simulation of gradient flows of probability measures. In Chen etÂ al. (2024) Gaussian mixtures are used to approximate the Fisher-Rao gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence. This corresponds to a time rescaling of the linear interpolation. In NÃ¼sken (2024); Maurais & Marzouk (2024) they approximate the latter curve by kernelizing the associated Poisson equation and simulating a corresponding interacting particle system. Closely related Stein variational gradient descent Liu & Wang (2016) kernelizes the Wasserstein gradient flow of the reverse KL divergence. Recently in Chehab & Korba (2024) they consider a different path which they term the â€dilation pathâ€. The associated vector field is given as the gradient of the dilation of the target density. The convolution of the density of the dilation path with (scaled) Gaussian kernels corresponds to the density of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process.
Recently, (stochastic) normalizing flows have been widely used to sample from unnormalized densities NoÃ© etÂ al. (2019); Wu etÂ al. (2020); Hagemann etÂ al. (2022). In Midgley etÂ al. (2023) this problem is tackled without using a curve of probability measures by augmenting normalizing flows, which are trained using an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-divergence loss, with annealed importance sampling. In Hertrich & Gruhlke (2024) a functional Fğ¹Fitalic_F with minimum ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is considered. They then learn a vector field by approximating a JKO scheme for the Wasserstein gradient flow of Fğ¹Fitalic_F and combine it with an importance based rejection method. They focus on Fğ¹Fitalic_F being the Kullback Leibner divergence with target distribution ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Using KL for sampling is a natural choice and it is shown in Chen etÂ al. (2023) that it is the only fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence such that the Wasserstein gradient flow does not depend on the normalization constant of ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
Note that parametrizing the vector field using the score âˆ‡logâ¡ptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\nabla\log p_{t}âˆ‡ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is common practice for sampling via SDEs. In Zhang & Chen (2022) for example where they formulate the sampling problem in terms of a stochastic control problem and explicitly include the score into the parametrization of the vector field. The stochastic control viewpoint is also used in (Berner etÂ al., 2024, Section 3) where the KL divergence between path measures associated to a controlled and an uncontrolled SDE is used to approximate the score. A different approach using the KL on path measures is formulated in Vargas etÂ al. (2023). Another way of approximating a flow ending in ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is to consider the variance exploding diffusion SDE and approximating the score âˆ‡logâ¡ptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\nabla\log p_{t}âˆ‡ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is done in Akhound-Sadegh etÂ al. (2024).

The authors of MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) present a loss based on the continuity equation and the special form eâˆ’ftZtsuperscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\frac{e^{-f_{t}}}{Z_{t}}divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG of Boltzmann densities. This loss allows for using fixed interpolations ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and only learning vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as learning ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT simultaneously. When finishing this paper, we became aware of the recent preprint of Sun etÂ al. (2024) comparing a variety of PDE based sampling methods. They included a similar approach as the one proposed here, using the same parametrization to simulate an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck SDE. However, coming from the Wasserstein perspective, we came to the conclusion that the associated gradient flow path is especially well-behaved. We simulate the corresponding ODE and highlight its benefits.
For the proof that many Boltzmann density curves are absolutely continuous Wasserstein curves, the main object of interest is

âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢âˆ‡st)=(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢Ït,tâˆˆ[0,1]formulae-sequenceâ‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¡01\displaystyle-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}\right)=\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1]- âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] (2)

which relates Fisher-Rao curves and Wasserstein absolutely continuous curves. This equation was studied for a fixed time tğ‘¡titalic_t in various contexts. In nonlinear filtering it is used to study weak solutions of nonlinear filters see e.g. (Laugesen etÂ al., 2014, Section 2.1). Their theory for fixed time steps tğ‘¡titalic_t can be generalized to the case of a time dependent equation as seen in Section A.1. The close relationship between the Poincare inequality and fixed time solutions of (2) is discussed in Dhara & KaÅ‚amajska (2015).

2 Wasserstein Flows of Boltzmann Densities

2.1 General Background

Let ğ’«â¢(â„d)ğ’«superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d})caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) denote the space of probability measures on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For Î¼âˆˆğ’«â¢(â„d)ğœ‡ğ’«superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mu\in\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_Î¼ âˆˆ caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), let Lpâ¢(â„d,Î¼)superscriptğ¿ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğœ‡L^{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ ), pâˆˆ[1,âˆ)ğ‘1p\in[1,\infty)italic_p âˆˆ [ 1 , âˆ ), denotes the Banach space of (equivalence classes of) real-valued functions on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with finite norm â€–fâ€–Lpâ¢(â„d,Î¼)â‰”(âˆ«â„d|f|pâ¢dÎ¼)1/pâ‰”subscriptnormğ‘“subscriptğ¿ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘differential-dğœ‡1ğ‘\|f\|_{L_{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)}\coloneqq\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|f|^{p}\,% \mathrm{d}\mu\right)^{1/p}âˆ¥ italic_f âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” ( âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Î¼ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Lpâ¢(â„d,â„d,Î¼)subscriptğ¿ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğœ‡L_{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ ) be the Banach space of Borel vector fields v:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ‘£â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ In complete metric spaces, we can consider absolutely continuous curves depending on the metric of the space. 2.2 Wasserstein meets Fisher-Rao Flows

In the following, we are interested in absolutely continuous probability measures with respect to the Lebesgue measure, i.e., the space ğ’«aâ¢c(â„d)â‰”{Î¼=Ïdx:ÏâˆˆL1(â„d)\mathcal{P}^{ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\coloneqq\{\mu=\rho\,\mathrm{d}x:\rho\in L_{1}% (\mathbb{R}^{d})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰” { italic_Î¼ = italic_Ï roman_d italic_x : italic_Ï âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), Ïâ‰¥0ğœŒ0\rho\geq 0italic_Ï â‰¥ 0, âˆ«â„dÏdx=1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\rho\,\mathrm{d}x=1\}âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï roman_d italic_x = 1 } and we will address such measures just by their densities. Moreover, we will only consider Boltzmann/Gibbs densities depending on functions f:[0,1]Ã—â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R with eâˆ’ftâˆˆL1â¢(â„d)superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿1superscriptâ„ğ‘‘e^{-f_{t}}\in L_{1}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and fâ¢(â‹…,x)âˆˆC1â¢([0,1])ğ‘“â‹…ğ‘¥superscriptğ¶101f(\cdot,x)\in C^{1}([0,1])italic_f ( â‹… , italic_x ) âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] ) for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and âˆ‚tfâ¢(t,â‹…)âˆˆL2â¢(â„d,Ït)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\partial_{t}f(t,\cdot)\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that

Ïtâ‰”eâˆ’ftZt,Ztâ‰”âˆ«Rdeâˆ’ftâ¢dx.formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡â‰”subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¥\rho_{t}\coloneqq\frac{e^{-f_{t}}}{Z_{t}},\quad Z_{t}\coloneqq\int_{R^{d}}e^{-% f_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}x.italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x . (8)

In this case, straightforward computation gives

âˆ‚Î¼t=âˆ‚tÏtsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle\partial\mu_{t}=\partial_{t}\rho_{t}âˆ‚ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =âˆ’(âˆ‚tftâˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft])â¢Ït,absentsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle=-\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}% ]\right)\rho_{t},= - ( âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (9)

where it maybe useful to note that

ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft]=âˆ’âˆ‚tlogâ¡Zt.subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]=-\partial_{t}\log Z_{t}.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = - âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

This differential equation is a Fisher-Rao flow equation. More precisely, a weakly continuous curve Ï:[0,1]â†’ğ’«aâ¢câ¢(â„d):ğœŒâ†’01superscriptğ’«ğ‘ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\rho:[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_Ï : [ 0 , 1 ] â†’ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), tâ†¦Ïtmaps-toğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡t\mapsto\rho_{t}italic_t â†¦ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Fisher-Rao curve, if there exists a measurable map Î±:[0,1]Ã—â„dâ†’â„:ğ›¼â†’01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\alpha:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_Î± : [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R such that Î±t:=Î±â¢(t,â‹…)âˆˆL2â¢(â„d,Ït)assignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\alpha_{t}:=\alpha(t,\cdot)\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_Î± ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and we have in a distibutional sense

âˆ‚tÏt=(Î±tâˆ’Î±Â¯t)â¢Ït,Î±Â¯tâ‰”ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[Î±t].formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptÂ¯ğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‰”subscriptÂ¯ğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=(\alpha_{t}-\bar{\alpha}_{t})\rho_{t},\quad\bar{\alpha}_{% t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\alpha_{t}].âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . (10)

Obviously, (9) delivers a Fisher-Rao curve with Î±tâ‰”âˆ’âˆ‚tftâ‰”subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡\alpha_{t}\coloneqq-\partial_{t}f_{t}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” - âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For more information on Fisher-Rao flows see, e.g., GallouÃ«t & Monsaingeon (2017); Wang & Li (2022). We are interested in the question under which conditions a Fisher-Rao curve determined by (9) is also an absolutely continuous curve in the Wasserstein space. For later purposes, note that for Boltzmann densities (8), the second summand of the continuity equation (4) reads as

âˆ‡â‹…(Î¼tâ¢vt)=âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢vt)=(âˆ’âŸ¨âˆ‡ft,vtâŸ©+âˆ‡â‹…vt)â¢Ït.â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\nabla\cdot(\mu_{t}v_{t})=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}v_{t})=\left(-\langle\nabla f_{t% },v_{t}\rangle+\nabla\cdot v_{t}\right)\rho_{t}.âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( - âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© + âˆ‡ â‹… italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (11)

Nevertheless, using (9), for our Fisher-Rao curves the continuity equation becomes

(âˆ‚tftâˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft])â¢Ït=âˆ‡â‹…(Ït,vt),subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]\right)\rho_{t% }=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t},v_{t}),( âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (12)

and in the ideal case that we can find a vector field vt=âˆ‡stsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, compare (6), this can be rewritten as the family of Poisson equations

(âˆ‚tftâˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft])â¢Ït=âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢âˆ‡st),subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]\right)\rho_{t% }=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}),( âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (13)

which needs to be solved for stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For fixed time tğ‘¡titalic_t, the solution of the Poisson equation has already been examined, e.g., in Laugesen etÂ al. (2014) and for more recent work, see also Reich (2011); Taghvaei & Mehta (2023). To our best knowledge, the following two theorems, which are detailed in Appendix A.1, tackle a rigorous solution of this problem for the first time.

Theorem 1.

Assume that ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï determined by âˆ«[0,1]Ã—â„dfâ¢(t,x)â¢dğ›’=âˆ«01âˆ«â„dfâ¢(t,x)â¢dÏtâ¢dtsubscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¥differential-dğ›’superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¥differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}=\int_{0}^{% 1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}tâˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d bold_italic_Ï = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t satisfies a so-called partial Poincare inequality, see Definition A.7, for some K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0, and that 1ğ›’1ğ›’\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_Ï end_ARG is locally integrable. Theorem 2.

âˆ«01âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡xğ’”tâ€–2â¢dÏtâ¢dtâ‰¤Kâ¢âˆ«01âˆ«â„d(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)2â¢dÏtâ¢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ’”ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}\boldsymbol{s}_{t}\|% ^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}% \left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d% }t.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t â‰¤ italic_K âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . Note that by the Benamou-Brenier formula, see (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Equation 8.0.3), the left-hand side of (15) is an upper bound for the Wasserstein distance W22â¢(Ï0,Ï1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š22subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the double-integral on the right-hand side defines the Fisher-Rao action of ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Neural Sampling from Boltzmann Densities

Our aim is to sample from a Boltzmann measure Î¼D=ÏDâ¢dâ¢xsubscriptğœ‡ğ·subscriptğœŒğ·dğ‘¥\mu_{D}=\rho_{D}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x, where we only have access to fD:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ·â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{D}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R, but not to the normalization constant ZDsubscriptğ‘ğ·Z_{D}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by following a measure flow starting in a simple to sample measure Î¼Z=ÏZâ¢dâ¢xsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘subscriptğœŒğ‘dğ‘¥\mu_{Z}=\rho_{Z}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x like the standard Gaussian one. We apply the continuity equation (12) of Fisher-Rao curves, which can be rewritten by (11) and division by Ït>0subscriptğœŒğ‘¡0\rho_{t}>0italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 as

âˆ‚tftâˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft]âŸCt=âˆ’âŸ¨âˆ‡ft,vtâŸ©+âˆ‡â‹…vt.subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptâŸsubscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡\partial_{t}f_{t}-\underbrace{\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]}_{C_{t}% }=-\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t}\rangle+\nabla\cdot v_{t}.âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - underâŸ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© + âˆ‡ â‹… italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (16)

Indeed every spatially constant function Ctsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which fulfills the above equation must be of the form Ct=ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tft]subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡C_{t}=\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], see MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023). This enables us to learn Ctsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that (16) does no longer depend on normalization constants. We will deal with the following parameterizations of ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and how to learn them:

  1. 1.

    linear interpolation: ftâ‰”(1âˆ’t)â¢fZ+tâ¢fDâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â â†ªâ†ª\hookrightarrowâ†ª learn vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

    learned interpolation by MÃ¡tÃ© and Fleuret: ftâ‰”(1âˆ’t)â¢fZ+tâ¢fD+tâ¢(1âˆ’t)â¢Ïˆtâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â â†ªâ†ª\hookrightarrowâ†ª learn (Ïˆt,vt)subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡(\psi_{t},v_{t})( italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

  3. 3.

    gradient flow interpolation: ftâ‰”Tâˆ’tTâ¢fD+tâ¢Ïˆtâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}\coloneqq\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, vtâ‰”âˆ‡(ftâˆ’fZ)â‰”subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla(f_{t}-f_{Z})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‡ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) Â â†ªâ†ª\hookrightarrowâ†ª learn Ïˆtsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡\psi_{t}italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

While by definition the first two settings interpolate between ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï0=ÏZsubscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{0}=\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ï1=ÏDsubscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{1}=\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we will see that the newly proposed third variant interpolates between ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the choice of vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., Ï0=ÏDsubscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{0}=\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and limTâ†’âˆÏT=ÏZsubscriptâ†’ğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘\lim_{T\to\infty}\rho_{T}=\rho_{Z}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In practice we reparametrize the latter curve into unit time, see Remark 3.

3.1 Linear & Learned Interpolation

Linear interpolation.

The simplest interpolation is the linear one ftâ‰”(1âˆ’t)â¢fZ+tâ¢fDâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., ÏtâˆÏ01âˆ’tâ¢Ï1tproportional-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœŒ01ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœŒ1ğ‘¡\rho_{t}\propto\rho_{0}^{1-t}\rho_{1}^{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under suitable conditions on the end points this density fulfills the assumptions of Theorem 2, see Corollary A.17 in the Appendix, and is therefore a Wasserstein curve. By (9), it also defines a Fisher-Rao curve, and the corresponding Fisher-Rao flow equation (10) is given by

âˆ‚tÏtsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(f0âˆ’f1âˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[f0âˆ’f1])â¢Ïtabsentsubscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle=\left(f_{0}-f_{1}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[f_{0}-f_{1}]\right)\rho_% {t}= ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (17)
=âˆ’(logâ¡(Ï0Ï1)âˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[logâ¡(Ï0Ï1)])â¢Ït.absentsubscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle=-\Big{(}\log(\frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho_{1}})-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[% \log(\frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho_{1}})]\Big{)}\rho_{t}.= - ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (18)

Note that, ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is even a Fisher-Rao gradient flow of the negative log likelihood, see also Maurais & Marzouk (2024), given by

â„°NLLâ¢(Ï):=âˆ’ğ”¼Ïâ¢[logâ¡(Ï1Ï0)].assignsubscriptâ„°NLLğœŒsubscriptğ”¼ğœŒdelimited-[]subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ0\displaystyle\mathcal{E}_{\rm NLL}(\rho):=-\mathbb{E}_{\rho}\left[\log(\frac{% \rho_{1}}{\rho_{0}})\right].caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_NLL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) := - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] . (19)

There are a variety of approaches for approximating the vector field corresponding to the linear interpolation. In Maurais & Marzouk (2024); NÃ¼sken (2024) a kernel-based method for solving (13) was proposed. In MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) they propose to solve (16) which in case of the linear interpolation becomes

f1âˆ’f0âˆ’Ct+âŸ¨âˆ‡ft,vtâŸ©âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…vt=0.subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡0\displaystyle f_{1}-f_{0}-C_{t}+\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t}\rangle-\nabla\cdot v% _{t}=0.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© - âˆ‡ â‹… italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . (20)

This equation has many solutions vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the same ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and in order to enforce uniqueness we could demand that vt=âˆ‡stsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This approach leads to learning neural networks (vtÎ¸1,CtÎ¸2)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£subscriptğœƒ1ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ¶subscriptğœƒ2ğ‘¡(v^{\theta_{1}}_{t},C^{\theta_{2}}_{t})( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by minimizing the loss function

â„°â¢(Î¸,x,t)â„°ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_x , italic_t ) â‰”|f1âˆ’f0âˆ’CtÎ¸2+âŸ¨âˆ‡ft,vtÎ¸1âŸ©âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…vtÎ¸1|2,Î¸â‰”(Î¸1,Î¸2).formulae-sequenceâ‰”absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“0superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒ2âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒ1â‹…âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒ12â‰”ğœƒsubscriptğœƒ1subscriptğœƒ2\displaystyle\coloneqq|f_{1}-f_{0}-C_{t}^{\theta_{2}}+\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t% }^{\theta_{1}}\rangle-\nabla\cdot v_{t}^{\theta_{1}}|^{2},\quad\theta\coloneqq% (\theta_{1},\theta_{2}).â‰” | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© - âˆ‡ â‹… italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î¸ â‰” ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (22)

A teleportation issue with the linear interpolation. MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) gave examples, where for an asymmetric constellation of target and prior measure, this path transports mass into distant modes only at very late times which may cause problems while learning the corresponding vector field. Mathematically, this corresponds to the fact that the vector field vtâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘¥v_{t}(x)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) develops a singularity in xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for late times tğ‘¡titalic_t, see (MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret, 2023, Figure 6). In this work, we demonstrate that this phenomenon is more severe: even when averaging over the space xğ‘¥xitalic_x, the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal field (5) explodes for late times tğ‘¡titalic_t. For an example in â„1superscriptâ„1\mathbb{R}^{1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT involving a Laplacian Ï0âˆeâˆ’|x|proportional-tosubscriptğœŒ0superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥\rho_{0}\propto e^{-|x|}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | italic_x | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT centered at 00 and a Laplacian-like distribution Ï1âˆeâˆ’2â¢minâ¡{|x|,|xâˆ’m|}proportional-tosubscriptğœŒ1superscriptğ‘’2ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘š\rho_{1}\propto e^{-2\min\{|x|,|x-m|\}}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 roman_min { | italic_x | , | italic_x - italic_m | } end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a mode at 00 and a second mode at m>0ğ‘š0m>0italic_m > 0, see Figure 1, we are able to give an explicit and analytic formula for the calculation of â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the Appendix A.4. Using this formula (71), we demonstrate that â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT explodes when tğ‘¡titalic_t is close to 1111, and that this explosion happens more severely and at later times, the further the second mode m>0ğ‘š0m>0italic_m > 0 is away from 00, see Figure 2.

Learned Interpolation.

To cope with the above disadvantages of the linear interpolation, MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) proposed to parameterize also the flow by ftâ‰”(1âˆ’t)â¢f0+tâ¢f1+tâ¢(1âˆ’t)â¢Ïˆtâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a neural network ÏˆtÎ¸1superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒ1\psi_{t}^{\theta_{1}}italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and to minimize according to (16) the above loss with

â„°â¢(Î¸,x,t):=|âˆ‚tftÎ¸1â¢(x)âˆ’CtÎ¸3+âŸ¨âˆ‡ftÎ¸1,vtÎ¸2âŸ©âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…vtÎ¸2|2,Î¸â‰”(Î¸1,Î¸2,Î¸3).formulae-sequenceassignâ„°ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğœƒ1ğ‘¡ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ¶subscriptğœƒ3ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğœƒ1ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£subscriptğœƒ2ğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£subscriptğœƒ2ğ‘¡2â‰”ğœƒsubscriptğœƒ1subscriptğœƒ2subscriptğœƒ3\displaystyle\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t):=|\partial_{t}f^{\theta_{1}}_{t}(x)-C^{% \theta_{3}}_{t}+\langle\nabla f^{\theta_{1}}_{t},v^{\theta_{2}}_{t}\rangle-% \nabla\cdot v^{\theta_{2}}_{t}|^{2},\quad\theta\coloneqq(\theta_{1},\theta_{2}% ,\theta_{3}).caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_x , italic_t ) := | âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© - âˆ‡ â‹… italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î¸ â‰” ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (23)

Since the approximation of high dimensional integrals is difficult, for both the linear and learned interpolation MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) propose to use an iterative approach by solving the ODE âˆ‚tÏ†tÎ¸â€²=vtÎ¸â€²â¢(Ï†tÎ¸â€²)subscriptğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğœƒâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£superscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğœƒâ€²\partial_{t}\varphi_{t}^{\theta^{\prime}}=v^{\theta^{\prime}}_{t}(\varphi_{t}^% {\theta^{\prime}})âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), Ï†0Î¸â€²=Idsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‘0superscriptğœƒâ€²Id\varphi_{0}^{\theta^{\prime}}=\mathrm{Id}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Id for Î¸â€²superscriptğœƒâ€²\theta^{\prime}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the previous minimization and to solve

Lâ¢(Î¸)â‰”ğ”¼tâˆˆğ’°â¢[0,1],zâˆ¼Ï0â¢[â„°â¢(Î¸,Ï†tÎ¸â€²â¢(z),t)].â‰”ğ¿ğœƒsubscriptğ”¼formulae-sequenceğ‘¡ğ’°01similar-toğ‘§subscriptğœŒ0delimited-[]â„°ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘§ğ‘¡\displaystyle L(\theta)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{t\in\mathcal{U}[0,1],z\sim\rho_{0}% }[\mathcal{E}(\theta,\varphi_{t}^{\theta^{\prime}}(z),t)].italic_L ( italic_Î¸ ) â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ caligraphic_U [ 0 , 1 ] , italic_z âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z ) , italic_t ) ] . (24)

Heuristically this penalizes â„°â¢(Î¸,x,t)â„°ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_x , italic_t ) stronger in regions where the intermediate solution has more mass. Finally, sampling can be done in both cases â€“ linear and learned interpolation â€“ assuming sufficient regularity of the learned vtÎ¸isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘–v_{t}^{\theta_{i}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, by simulating the ODE (7). Note that in general there are infinitely many solutions of (20) and neither the parameterized curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nor the vector field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unique. Further vtÎ¸2superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒ2v_{t}^{\theta_{2}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained in this way may not be minimal in any sense. The proof of the validity of the interpolation with respect to Theorem 2 is future work.

3.2 Gradient Flow Interpolation

Recall that the linear interpolation of the energies f0,f1subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to a multiplicative interpolation of densities Ïtâ¢(x)âˆÏZâ¢(x)1âˆ’tâ¢ÏDâ¢(x)tproportional-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘superscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ·superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\rho_{t}(x)\propto\rho_{Z}(x)^{1-t}\rho_{D}(x)^{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) âˆ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that this does not take account of any local behaviour of ÏZ,ÏDsubscriptğœŒğ‘subscriptğœŒğ·\rho_{Z},\rho_{D}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in a neighbourhood of xğ‘¥xitalic_x, resulting in irregular behavior of the vector field as shown in Figure 1 and 2. In contrast, widely used paths in generative modelling Song etÂ al. (2021); Lipman etÂ al. (2023) originate from an interpolation of densities via (spatial) convolutions Ïtâˆ¼ÏZâ¢(â‹…at)âˆ—ÏDâ¢(â‹…bt)similar-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ—subscriptğœŒğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ·â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\rho_{t}\sim\rho_{Z}(\frac{\cdot}{a_{t}})\ast\rho_{D}(\frac{\cdot}{b_{t}})italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG â‹… end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) âˆ— italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG â‹… end_ARG start_ARG italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) for time schedules at,btsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡a_{t},b_{t}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, corresponding to an interpolation Xt=atâ¢Z+btâ¢X0subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‹0X_{t}=a_{t}Z+b_{t}X_{0}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of associated independent random variables Zâˆ¼ÏZ,X0âˆ¼ÏDformulae-sequencesimilar-toğ‘subscriptğœŒğ‘similar-tosubscriptğ‘‹0subscriptğœŒğ·Z\sim\rho_{Z},X_{0}\sim\rho_{D}italic_Z âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the spatial level. We aim to learn such a curve and an associated vector field.

which fulfills Î¼t=Ï†~Tâˆ’t,â™¯â¢Î¼Zsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘¡subscript~ğœ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘¡â™¯subscriptğœ‡ğ‘\mu_{t}=\tilde{\varphi}_{T-t,\sharp}\mu_{Z}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_Ï† end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t , â™¯ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Relation to Wasserstein gradient flows.

Equation (25) is well-known in connection with Wasserstein gradient flows. A Wasserstein gradient flow is an absolutely continuous curve whose vector field vt=âˆ’gradÏtâ¢FâˆˆTÏtâ¢(ğ’«2â¢(â„d))subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptgradsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ¹subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v_{t}=-\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F\in T_{\rho_{t}}(\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d}))italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) is given by the negative Wasserstein gradient (or more generally, subdifferential) of a function F:ğ’«2â¢(â„d)â†’â„:ğ¹â†’subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„F:\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â†’ blackboard_R. Then, the continuity equation

âˆ‚tÏtâˆ’âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢gradÏtâ¢F)=0subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptgradsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ¹0\partial_{t}\rho_{t}-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F\right)=0âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ) = 0 (28)

produces a flow towards a minimizer of Fğ¹Fitalic_F. A prominent example, see, e.g. (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Chapter 10.4), is Fâ¢(Ï)â‰”KLâ¢(Ï|ÏZ)â‰”ğ¹ğœŒKLconditionalğœŒsubscriptğœŒğ‘F(\rho)\coloneqq\text{KL}(\rho|\rho_{Z})italic_F ( italic_Ï ) â‰” KL ( italic_Ï | italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) arising from the Kullback-Leibler divergence which has the unique minimizer ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since it is easy to show, see (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Lemma 10.4.1), that gradÏtâ¢F=âˆ‡logâ¡ÏtÏZsubscriptgradsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ¹âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F=\nabla\log\frac{\rho_{t}}{\rho_{Z}}grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F = âˆ‡ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , we can be rewrite (28) as

âˆ‚tÏt=âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢(âˆ‡logâ¡ÏZâˆ’âˆ‡logâ¡Ït)),Ï0=ÏD,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒğ·\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}(\nabla\log\rho_{Z% }-\nabla\log\rho_{t})\right),\quad\rho_{0}=\rho_{D},âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ roman_log italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âˆ‡ roman_log italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (29)

which is also known as the Fokker-Planck equation. Inserting Ïtâ‰”eâˆ’ft/Ztâ‰”subscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\rho_{t}\coloneqq e^{-f_{t}}/Z_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT results exactly in (25). The existence and uniqueness of a solution of (29) is shown in (Ambrosio & SavarÃ©, 2007, Theorem 6.6). However, it is not clear if Boltzmann densities stay Boltzmann densities. But in the special case, when ÏZsubscriptğœŒğ‘\rho_{Z}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Gaussian, this is the case as we will see next.
There is a close relation between (29) and SDEs, namely the Langevin SDE

dâ¢Xt=âˆ‡logâ¡ÏZâ¢(Xt)â¢dâ¢t+2â¢dâ¢Btdsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡dğ‘¡2dsubscriptğµğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathrm{d}X_{t}=\nabla\log\rho_{Z}(X_{t})\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{2}% \mathrm{d}B_{t}roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ roman_log italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (30)

corresponds to the Fokker-Planck equation (29), see e.g., (Chewi etÂ al., 2024, Chapter 6.2), i.e., Xtâˆ¼Ïtsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡X_{t}\sim\rho_{t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For ÏZâˆğ’©â¢(0,Id)proportional-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘ğ’©0subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘\rho_{Z}\propto\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (30) becomes dâ¢Xt=âˆ’Xtâ¢dâ¢t+2â¢dâ¢Btdsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡dğ‘¡2dsubscriptğµğ‘¡\mathrm{d}X_{t}=-X_{t}\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{2}\mathrm{d}B_{t}roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, which has the closed form solution

Xt=eâˆ’tâ¢Z+eâˆ’tâ¢X0,Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,(e2â¢tâˆ’1)â¢Id),X0âˆ¼ÏD,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‹0formulae-sequencesimilar-toğ‘ğ’©0superscriptğ‘’2ğ‘¡1subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘similar-tosubscriptğ‘‹0subscriptğœŒğ·X_{t}=e^{-t}Z+e^{-t}X_{0},\quad Z\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,(e^{2t}-1)I_{d}\right)% ,\quad X_{0}\sim\rho_{D},italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is independent from X0subscriptğ‘‹0X_{0}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, see (Herrmann & Massin, 2019, Eq. (2.4)). From the closed form solution it follows that Ïtâˆ¼ğ’©(0,(1âˆ’eâˆ’2â¢t)Id)âˆ—ÏD(etâ‹…)>0\rho_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,(1-e^{-2t})I_{d}\right)*\rho_{D}\left(e^{t}% \cdot\right)>0italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ— italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… ) > 0, and thus Ïtâˆeâˆ’ftproportional-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡\rho_{t}\propto e^{-f_{t}}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which implies that (25) has a solution.

Remark 3.

The dynamics of both the linear and learned interpolations are on the unit interval. To obtain dynamics on the unit interval for the gradient flow interpolation we apply an approach from the score based diffusion literature Song etÂ al. (2021). We use a linear time schedule Î²â¢(t):=Î²min+tâ¢(Î²maxâˆ’Î²min)assignğ›½ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½minğ‘¡subscriptğ›½maxsubscriptğ›½min\beta(t):=\beta_{\text{min}}+t\left(\beta_{\text{max}}-\beta_{\text{min}}\right)italic_Î² ( italic_t ) := italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the associated SDE

dâ¢Xt=âˆ’12â¢Î²â¢(t)â¢Xtâ¢dâ¢t+Î²â¢(t)â¢dâ¢BtX0âˆ¼Ï1.formulae-sequencedsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡12ğ›½ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡dğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘¡dsubscriptğµğ‘¡similar-tosubscriptğ‘‹0subscriptğœŒ1\displaystyle\mathrm{d}X_{t}=-\frac{1}{2}\beta(t)X_{t}\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{\beta(% t)}\mathrm{d}B_{t}\quad X_{0}\sim\rho_{1}.roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Î² ( italic_t ) italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG italic_Î² ( italic_t ) end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (31)

The SDE (31) has a closed form solution given by

Xt=1âˆ’eâˆ’gâ¢(t)â¢Z+eâˆ’gâ¢(t)2â¢X0,subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘‹0X_{t}=\sqrt{1-e^{-g(t)}}Z+e^{\frac{-g(t)}{2}}X_{0},italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_g ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_Z + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG - italic_g ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (32)

where gâ¢(t):=âˆ«0tÎ²â¢(s)â¢dsassignğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘ differential-dğ‘ g(t):=\int_{0}^{t}\beta(s)\,\mathrm{d}sitalic_g ( italic_t ) := âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² ( italic_s ) roman_d italic_s and Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,Id)similar-toğ‘ğ’©0subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘Z\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})italic_Z âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). As done in Song etÂ al. (2021) we choose Î²min=0.1subscriptğ›½min0.1\beta_{\text{min}}=0.1italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.1 and Î²max=20subscriptğ›½max20\beta_{\text{max}}=20italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 20. These choices ensure that the distribution of X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is approximately ğ’©â¢(0,Id)ğ’©0subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We then aim to learn the solution of the associated Fokker-Planck equation, this corresponds to setting vtâ‰”Î²â¢(t)2â¢âˆ‡(ftâˆ’âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥22)v_{t}\coloneqq\frac{\beta(t)}{2}\nabla(f_{t}-\frac{\|\cdot\|^{2}}{2})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” divide start_ARG italic_Î² ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ‡ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ).

4 Experiments

In this section we apply the different approaches to common sampling problems. We compare the performance of using the linear, learned or gradient flow interpolation.

For both the linear interpolation and the learned interpolation, we can choose to learn the vector field directly, or learn a potential and obtain the vector field as its gradient. In practice, we choose to parameterize it directly as in MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023). Note that in practice for the gradient flow interpolation we apply Remark 3. Furthermore we improve performance by using learned scheduling function gâ¢(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ), satisfying gâ¢(0)=1ğ‘”01g(0)=1italic_g ( 0 ) = 1 and gâ¢(1)=0ğ‘”10g(1)=0italic_g ( 1 ) = 0, and parametrizing the corresponding ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ft:=gâ¢(t)â¢fD+tâ¢Ïˆtassignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡f_{t}:=g(t)f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_g ( italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

A major design choice is at which points to evaluate the pointwise error â„°â¢(Î¸,x,t)â„°ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_x , italic_t ). The approach taken in MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) is to use samples along the trajectory induced by the current estimate of vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the gradient flow interpolation, we chose a different approach. We sample points uniformly from a large enough domain and interpolate them with samples from our latent distribution according to the formula given in (32), where we replace the samples from the data distribution with random uniform ones. For the linear and learned interpolation we tried similar approaches sampling the points from scaled uniform domains. However, we found in our experiments that the method employed in MÃ¡tÃ© & Fleuret (2023) led to better performance.

In the following, we evaluate the methods using the effective sample size, negative log likelihood and the energy distance SzÃ©kely & Rizzo (2013). See A.5 for further details on the implementation and evaluation.

Gaussian Mixture Model.

We use the experimental setup from Midgley etÂ al. (2023). The target distribution consists of a mixture of 40 evenly weighted Gaussians in 2 dimensions. The means are distributed uniformly over [âˆ’40,40]2superscript40402[-40,40]^{2}[ - 40 , 40 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

In Figure 3 we plot the countour lines of the target distribution as well as 1000 samples from the simulated flow and the ground truth, respectively.

For this experiment an important factor is the choice of latent distribution. We restricted ourselves to using a Gaussian latent distribution. However as outlined in Section 3.1 the linear interpolation faces difficulties when some modes are far away from the latent while others are close. In order to mitigate this problem, we experimented with using varying standard deviations Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ; the impact of this choice is visualized in A.5. We found that using a mode covering Gaussian led to the best results. In contrast, the gradient flow interpolation works well when starting in a standard Gaussian which is what we do.

Many Well Distribution.

The target is a 8888-dimensional many well distribution and we use the implementation of the target energy from Midgley etÂ al. (2023). More precisely we consider the 4444-fold product distribution of the two dimensional density given by

logâ¡pâ¢(x1,x2)=âˆ’x14+6â¢x12+12â¢x1âˆ’12â¢x22+constantğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥146superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1212subscriptğ‘¥112superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥22constant\displaystyle\log p(x_{1},x_{2})=-x_{1}^{4}+6x_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{1}-\frac{% 1}{2}x_{2}^{2}+\text{constant}roman_log italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 6 italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + constant (33)

as target distribution. The results in Table 2 show that both the learned and gradient flow interpolations significantly outperform the linear interpolation. The learned interpolation works especially well in this setting. Here the choice of latent distribution is not as relevant as starting in a standard Gaussian is sufficient for all methods, since the modes of the many well distribution are concentrated close to zero.

5 Conclusions

Discussion.

We studied different paths in the probability space in order to sample from unnormalized densities and compared their behaviour and computibility. The linear interpolation of energies suffers from an exploding vector field, and learning the vector field and energy path simultaneously (learned interpolation) in practice solves this problem. However, there is no theoretical knowledge about the path which we want to approximate and in turn no conclusions about the regularity of the corresponding vector field can be drawn. In contrast, the proposed gradient flow approach allows for a thorough mathematical description of the velocity field and the path itself, opening the doors for a rigorous analysis via Wasserstein gradient flows and Fokker-Planck equations. We show numerical performance on sampling from Gaussian mixture models and a many well distribution. Furthermore we close a gap in the literature by showing that a large class of Fisher Rao curves and in particular curves of Boltzmann densities are in fact absolutely continuous curves in the Wasserstein geometry. Hence the existence of a corresponding vector field driving the evolution is implied, justifying sampling from the target density via solving an ODE.

Limitations and Outlook.

The methods proposed require knowledge of the domain of the target distribution. Furthermore solving PDEs in high dimensional settings remains challenging. These issues can be addressed by developing more efficient strategies to sample points at which to evaluate the loss â„°â¢(Î¸,x,t)â„°ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_Î¸ , italic_x , italic_t ), such as combining uniform sampling and trajectory based sampling. From a theoretical point of view further investigation of the behaviour and regularity of the gradient flow path is needed, especially the behaviour of the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would be of interest.
