Appendix A Appendix

A.1 Wasserstein meets Fisher-Rao: Solution of a family of Poisson Equations

We will show that under mild assumptions on fğ‘“fitalic_f, the Fisher-Rao curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from (9) is also a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve with a tangent vector field âˆ‡stâˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡\nabla s_{t}âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT222Overall, let âˆ‡:=âˆ‡xassignâˆ‡subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥\nabla:=\nabla_{x}âˆ‡ := âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote differentiation in direction xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.. In order to do that, we will describe stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the unique solution of a Poisson equation in a suitable Hilbert space ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. More precisely, we show that there exists a unique sâˆˆL2â¢([0,1]Ã—â„d;ğ†)ğ‘ subscriptğ¿201superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ†s\in L_{2}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d};\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_s âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Ï ) (with ğ†ğ†\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï given by Definition A.1) such that âˆ‡st:=âˆ‡sâ¢(t,â‹…)assignâˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…\nabla s_{t}:=\nabla s(t,\cdot)âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âˆ‡ italic_s ( italic_t , â‹… ) fulfills the Poisson equation

âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢âˆ‡st)=(âˆ‚tfâˆ’ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[âˆ‚tf])â¢Ïtâ‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\displaystyle\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t})=\Big{(}\partial_{t}f-\mathbb{E}% _{\rho_{t}}\left[\partial_{t}f\right]\Big{)}\rho_{t}âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ] ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (34)

in a distributional sense in ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For fixed time tğ‘¡titalic_t, this has already been done, e.g., in Laugesen etÂ al. (2014). But note that a pointwise-in-time treatment does not allow us to conclude Wasserstein absolute continuity of our curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, we generalize their methods to a global-in-time ansatz; in particular, under suitable assumptions on fğ‘“fitalic_f, we find a unique weak solution sğ‘ sitalic_s of (34) such that

  1. 1.

    âˆ‡xssubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ \nabla_{x}sâˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is Borel measurable on [0,1]Ã—â„d01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

    tâ†¦â€–âˆ‡xsâ¢(t,â‹…)â€–L2â¢(Ït)2âˆˆL1â¢([0,1])maps-toğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡2subscriptğ¿101t\mapsto\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}\in L_{1}([0,1])italic_t â†¦ âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] ), Â i.e., âˆ«01â€–âˆ‡xsâ¢(t,â‹…)â€–L2â¢(Ït)2â¢dt<âˆsuperscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡2differential-dğ‘¡\int_{0}^{1}\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}\,\mathrm{d}t<\inftyâˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_t < âˆ,

    âˆ‡xsâ¢(t,â‹…)âˆˆTÏtâ¢ğ’«2â¢(â„d)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

These conditions ensure that the Fisher-Rao curve (9) is absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein sense, and that the velocity field âˆ‡xssubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ \nabla_{x}sâˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is the optimal one fulfilling the continuity equation w.r.t. our curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as described in (5).

As a by-product, we obtain the estimate

âˆ«01âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡xsâ¢(t,â‹…)â€–2â¢dÏtâ¢dtâ‰¤Kâ¢âˆ«01âˆ«â„d(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)2â¢dÏtâ¢dt,superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|^{2}\,% \mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(% \alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t,âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t â‰¤ italic_K âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t , (35)

linking (an upper bound of) the Wasserstein-2 distance W22â¢(Ï0,Ï1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š22subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on the one side, and the Fisher-Rao action on the other.

Next we will define the appropriate spaces for our analysis.

A.2 Prerequisites for solving the Poisson equation

Definition A.1.

Let tâ†¦Ïtmaps-toğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡t\mapsto\rho_{t}italic_t â†¦ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a weakly continuous curve [0,1]â†’ğ’«acâ¢(â„d)â†’01superscriptğ’«acsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})[ 0 , 1 ] â†’ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Thus, ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï defined by the disintegration âˆ«[0,1]Ã—â„dfâ¢(t,x)â¢dğ›’=âˆ«01âˆ«â„dfâ¢(t,x)â¢dÏtâ¢dtsubscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¥differential-dğ›’superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¥differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}=\int_{0}^{% 1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}tâˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d bold_italic_Ï = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t, is a probability measure on [0,1]Ã—â„d01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, see e.g., (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Chapter 5.3).

Lemma A.3.

Assume that Ïâ¢dâ¢xâˆˆğ’«acâ¢(â„d)ğœŒdğ‘¥superscriptğ’«acsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\rho\,\mathrm{d}x\in\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_Ï roman_d italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and 1ÏâˆˆL1,locâ¢(â„d)1ğœŒsubscriptğ¿1locsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\frac{1}{\rho}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}(\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, (H1â¢(Ï),âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©H1â¢(Ï))superscriptğ»1ğœŒsubscriptâ‹…â‹…superscriptğ»1ğœŒ(H^{1}(\rho),\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{H^{1}(\rho)})( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) , âŸ¨ â‹… , â‹… âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Hilbert space and H01â¢(Ï)superscriptsubscriptğ»01ğœŒH_{0}^{1}(\rho)italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) is a closed subspace.

Proof.

The first claim is (Kufner & Opic, 1984, Theorem 1.11). For the second claim note that for fnâ†’fâ†’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘“f_{n}\to fitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_f in H1â¢(Ï)superscriptğ»1ğœŒH^{1}(\rho)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) with fnâˆˆH01â¢(Ï)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ»10ğœŒf_{n}\in H^{1}_{0}(\rho)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ), we have that

|âˆ«â„dfâ¢dÏ|subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“differential-dğœŒ\displaystyle\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f\,\mathrm{d}\rho\right|| âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f roman_d italic_Ï | =|âŸ¨f,1âŸ©L2â¢(Ï)|â‰¤|âŸ¨fâˆ’fn,1âŸ©L2â¢(Ï)|+|âŸ¨fn,1âŸ©L2â¢(Ï)|absentsubscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ¿2ğœŒsubscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›1subscriptğ¿2ğœŒsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›1subscriptğ¿2ğœŒ\displaystyle=|\langle f,1\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho)}|\leq|\langle f-f_{n},1\rangle_% {L_{2}(\rho)}|+|\langle f_{n},1\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho)}|= | âŸ¨ italic_f , 1 âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ | âŸ¨ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | âŸ¨ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (39)
â‰¤â€–fnâˆ’fâ€–H1â¢(Ï)+0â†’0.absentsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘“superscriptğ»1ğœŒ0â†’0\displaystyle\leq\|f_{n}-f\|_{H^{1}(\rho)}+0\to 0.â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 0 â†’ 0 . (40)

âˆ

Definition A.4.

Consider a weakly continuous curve [0,1]â†’ğ’«acâ¢(â„d),tâ†¦Ïtformulae-sequenceâ†’01superscriptğ’«acsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘maps-toğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d}),~{}t\mapsto\rho_{t}[ 0 , 1 ] â†’ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_t â†¦ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the associated measure ğ›’âˆˆğ’«acâ¢([0,1]Ã—â„d)ğ›’superscriptğ’«ac01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{\rho}\in\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})bold_italic_Ï âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) given by Definition A.1. Define

Hx1(ğ†)â‰”{fâˆˆL2([0,1]Ã—â„d,ğ†):Â the weak derivativeÂ âˆ‚xifÂ exists and\displaystyle H_{x}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\rho})\coloneqq\Big{\{}f\in L_{2}([0,1]% \times\mathbb{R}^{d},\boldsymbol{\rho}):\text{ the weak derivative }\partial_{% x_{i}}f\text{ exists and }italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) â‰” { italic_f âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Ï ) : the weak derivative âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f exists and (41)
âˆ‚xifâˆˆL2(ğ†),âˆ€iâˆˆ{2,â€¦,d+1}}\displaystyle\partial_{x_{i}}f\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho}),~{}\forall i\in\{2,% \ldots,d+1\}\Big{\}}âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) , âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ { 2 , â€¦ , italic_d + 1 } } (42)

Lemma A.5.

Assume that 1ğ›’âˆˆL1,locâ¢([0,1]Ã—â„d)1ğ›’subscriptğ¿1loc01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_Ï end_ARG âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Definition A.6.

On ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we define an bilinear form by setting

Definition A.7.

We say that a probability measure ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï fulfills the partial Poincare inequality (PPI) if there exists K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0 such that

â€–gâ€–L2â¢(ğ†)2â‰¤Kâ¢â€–âˆ‡xgâ€–L2â¢(ğ†)2subscriptsuperscriptnormğ‘”2subscriptğ¿2ğ†ğ¾subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘”2subscriptğ¿2ğ†\displaystyle\|g\|^{2}_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}\leq K\|\nabla_{x}g\|^{2}_{L_% {2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}âˆ¥ italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_K âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (PPI)

for all gâˆˆğ’³01ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ’³01g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_g âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that usually it is formulated as Vâ¢aâ¢rÎ¼â¢[g]â‰¤Kâ¢â€–âˆ‡xgâ€–L2â¢(Î¼)2ğ‘‰ğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğœ‡delimited-[]ğ‘”ğ¾subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘”2subscriptğ¿2ğœ‡Var_{{\mu}}[g]\leq K\|\nabla_{x}g\|^{2}_{L_{2}({\mu})}italic_V italic_a italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ] â‰¤ italic_K âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but since we have ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[gt]=0subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡0\mathbb{E}_{{\rho_{t}}}[g_{t}]=0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 for gâˆˆğ’³01ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ’³01g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_g âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT both notions coincide.

Lemma A.8.

Assume that ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï fulfills the (PPI), and that 1ğ›’âˆˆL1,locâ¢([0,1]Ã—â„d)1ğ›’subscriptğ¿1loc01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_Ï end_ARG âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, (ğ’³01,âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©ğ’³01)superscriptsubscriptğ’³01subscriptâ‹…â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ’³01({\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}})( caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âŸ¨ â‹… , â‹… âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Hilbert space.

Proof.

We have to show that âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©ğ’³01subscriptâ‹…â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}âŸ¨ â‹… , â‹… âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is positive definite and ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is complete. The first claim follows directly from the (PPI). The second follows from the fact that âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥Hx1â¢(ğ†)â‰¤K+1âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥ğ’³01â‰¤K+1âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥Hx1â¢(ğ†)\|\cdot\|_{H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}\leq\sqrt{K+1}\|\cdot\|_{{\mathcal{X}_% {0}^{1}}}\leq\sqrt{K+1}\|\cdot\|_{H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_K + 1 end_ARG âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_K + 1 end_ARG âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is closed in Hx1â¢(ğ†)subscriptsuperscriptğ»1ğ‘¥ğ†H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ). âˆ

This assumption (PPI) is usually fulfilled in our setting as we discuss in the following.

Lemma A.9.

(Bakry etÂ al., 2008, Corollary 1.6) Let Î¼=eâˆ’Vâ¢(x)â¢dâ¢xğœ‡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‰ğ‘¥dğ‘¥\mu=e^{-V(x)}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Î¼ = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V ( italic_x ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x be a probability measure on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and assume that VâˆˆC2â¢(â„d)ğ‘‰superscriptğ¶2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘V\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_V âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) such that Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is lower bounded. Assume furthermore that there exists Î·>0,R~â‰¥0formulae-sequenceğœ‚0~ğ‘…0\eta>0,\tilde{R}\geq 0italic_Î· > 0 , over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG â‰¥ 0 such that for all â€–xâ€–>R~normğ‘¥~ğ‘…\|x\|>\tilde{R}âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ > over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG we have

âŸ¨x,âˆ‡Vâ¢(x)âŸ©â‰¥Î·â¢â€–xâ€–.ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğœ‚normğ‘¥\langle x,\nabla V(x)\rangle\geq\eta\|x\|.âŸ¨ italic_x , âˆ‡ italic_V ( italic_x ) âŸ© â‰¥ italic_Î· âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ .

âˆ«â„dÏ•2â¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â‰¤Câ¢âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡Ï•â€–2â¢dÎ¼.subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ï•2ğ‘¥differential-dğœ‡ğ¶subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormâˆ‡italic-Ï•2differential-dğœ‡\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi^{2}(x)\,\mathrm{d}\mu\leq C\int_{% \mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla\phi\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\mu.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_Î¼ â‰¤ italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Î¼ . (44)

The constant Cğ¶Citalic_C can be estimated as follows: Let Î²:=Î²V,R:=2â¢â€–Vâ€–Lâˆâ¢(Bâ¢(R))assignğ›½subscriptğ›½ğ‘‰ğ‘…assign2subscriptnormğ‘‰superscriptğ¿ğµğ‘…\beta:=\beta_{V,R}:=2\|V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}italic_Î² := italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 2 âˆ¥ italic_V âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There exist C1,Î·,R,C2,Î·,R,C3,Î·,R>0subscriptğ¶1ğœ‚ğ‘…subscriptğ¶2ğœ‚ğ‘…subscriptğ¶3ğœ‚ğ‘…0C_{1,\eta,R},C_{2,\eta,R},C_{3,\eta,R}>0italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 (not depending on Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V) and a universal constant D>0ğ·0D>0italic_D > 0 such that

Câ‰¤4â¢dÎ·2â¢(1+(C1,Î·,R+C2,Î·,Râ¢â€–âˆ‡Vâ€–Lâˆâ¢(Bâ¢(R))+C3,Î·,R)â¢Dâ¢R2â¢eÎ²).ğ¶4ğ‘‘superscriptğœ‚21subscriptğ¶1ğœ‚ğ‘…subscriptğ¶2ğœ‚ğ‘…subscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘‰superscriptğ¿ğµğ‘…subscriptğ¶3ğœ‚ğ‘…ğ·superscriptğ‘…2superscriptğ‘’ğ›½\displaystyle C\leq\frac{4d}{\eta^{2}}\Big{(}1+\left(C_{1,\eta,R}+C_{2,\eta,R}% \|\nabla V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}+C_{3,\eta,R}\right)D\,R^{2}e^{\beta}\Big{)}.italic_C â‰¤ divide start_ARG 4 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( 1 + ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_V âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 , italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_D italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (45)
Proof.

We first show the claim for all smooth Ï•âˆˆCâˆâ¢(â„d)âˆ©H1â¢(Î¼)italic-Ï•superscriptğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptğ»1ğœ‡\phi\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)italic_Ï• âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ) with zero mean. Unfortunately in (Bakry etÂ al., 2008, Corollary 1.6), the constants are not explicitly computed which is why we track them here. They consider for Î³=Î·/2ğ›¾ğœ‚2\gamma=\eta/2italic_Î³ = italic_Î· / 2 the function given by Wâ¢(x)=WÎ·,Râ¢(x):=eÎ³â¢â€–xâ€–ğ‘Šğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Šğœ‚ğ‘…ğ‘¥assignsuperscriptğ‘’ğ›¾normğ‘¥W(x)=W_{\eta,R}(x):=e^{\gamma\|x\|}italic_W ( italic_x ) = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for â€–xâ€–>Rnormğ‘¥ğ‘…\|x\|>Râˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ > italic_R, and smooth continuation for â€–xâ€–â‰¤Rnormğ‘¥ğ‘…\|x\|\leq Râˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_R. They show that, if for L:=Î”âˆ’âŸ¨âˆ‡V,âˆ‡â‹…âŸ©L:=\Delta-\langle\nabla V,\nabla\cdot\rangleitalic_L := roman_Î” - âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_V , âˆ‡ â‹… âŸ©, it holds that

Lâ¢Wâ‰¤âˆ’Î¸â¢Wâ¢(x)+bâ¢Ï‡Bâ¢(R),ğ¿ğ‘Šğœƒğ‘Šğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğœ’ğµğ‘…LW\leq-\theta W(x)+b\chi_{B(R)},italic_L italic_W â‰¤ - italic_Î¸ italic_W ( italic_x ) + italic_b italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

then, the inequality Vâ¢aâ¢rÎ¼â¢[Ï•]â‰¤Câ¢âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡Ï•2â€–â¢dÎ¼ğ‘‰ğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğœ‡delimited-[]italic-Ï•ğ¶subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘normâˆ‡superscriptitalic-Ï•2differential-dğœ‡Var_{\mu}[\phi]\leq C\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla\phi^{2}\|\,\mathrm{d}\muitalic_V italic_a italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï• ] â‰¤ italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_d italic_Î¼ is true with constant C=1Î¸â¢(1+bâ¢ÎºR)ğ¶1ğœƒ1ğ‘subscriptğœ…ğ‘…C=\frac{1}{\theta}(1+b\kappa_{R})italic_C = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ( 1 + italic_b italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where the constant ÎºRsubscriptğœ…ğ‘…\kappa_{R}italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be estimated by Dâ¢R2â¢eÎ²ğ·superscriptğ‘…2superscriptğ‘’ğ›½D\,R^{2}e^{\beta}italic_D italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. and thus the claim is true for Ï•âˆˆCâˆâ¢(â„d)âˆ©H1â¢(Î¼)italic-Ï•superscriptğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptğ»1ğœ‡\phi\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)italic_Ï• âˆˆ italic_C In order to extend this result to Ï•âˆˆH01â¢(Î¼)italic-Ï•subscriptsuperscriptğ»10ğœ‡\phi\in H^{1}_{0}(\mu)italic_Ï• âˆˆ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ), note that Ccâˆâ¢(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is dense in H1â¢(â„d)superscriptğ»1superscriptâ„ğ‘‘H^{1}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), see (Adams & Fournier, 2003, Cor. 3.23). Since by assumption, Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is lower bounded, i.e., eâˆ’Vsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘‰e^{-V}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is upper bounded, Ccâˆâ¢(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is also dense in H1â¢(Î¼)superscriptğ»1ğœ‡H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ) by Lebesgueâ€™s dominated convergence theorem. Now take a sequence (Ï•n)âˆˆCcâˆâ¢(â„d)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘(\phi_{n})\in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})( italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) converging to Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• in H1â¢(Î¼)superscriptğ»1ğœ‡H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ). Then, also Ï•n~:=Ï•nâˆ’âˆ«â„dÏ•nâ¢dÎ¼assign~subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›differential-dğœ‡\tilde{\phi_{n}}:=\phi_{n}-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi_{n}\,\mathrm{d}\muover~ start_ARG italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_Î¼ converges to Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• in H1â¢(Î¼)superscriptğ»1ğœ‡H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ), and Ï•n~âˆˆCâˆâ¢(â„d)âˆ©H1â¢(Î¼)~subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›superscriptğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptğ»1ğœ‡\tilde{\phi_{n}}\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)over~ start_ARG italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ) has zero mean. The first part now yields the claim. âˆ

For the specific path ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by the linear potential interpolation Vt=(1âˆ’t)â¢f0+tâ¢f1subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the disintegration measure ğ†ğ†\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï fulfills the partial Poincare inequality (PPI) given suitable assumptions on the end points f0,f1subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the next proposition shows.

Proposition A.10.

Let f0,f1âˆˆC2â¢(â„d)subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1superscriptğ¶2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f_{0},f_{1}\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be lower bounded such that there exists Î±,Î·>0ğ›¼ğœ‚0\alpha,\eta>0italic_Î± , italic_Î· > 0 and R~>0~ğ‘…0\tilde{R}>0over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG > 0 such that for all â€–xâ€–â‰¥R~normğ‘¥~ğ‘…\|x\|\geq\tilde{R}âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ â‰¥ over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG it holds the drift condition

âŸ¨x,âˆ‡fiâ¢(x)âŸ©â‰¥Î·â¢â€–xâ€–,i=0,1,formulae-sequenceğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğœ‚normğ‘¥ğ‘–01\langle x,\nabla f_{i}(x)\rangle\geq\eta\|x\|,\quad i=0,1,âŸ¨ italic_x , âˆ‡ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) âŸ© â‰¥ italic_Î· âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ , italic_i = 0 , 1 , (49)

and the linear growth condition

fiâ¢(x)â‰¥Î±â¢â€–xâ€–,i=0,1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ›¼normğ‘¥ğ‘–01f_{i}(x)\geq\alpha\|x\|,\quad i=0,1.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) â‰¥ italic_Î± âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ , italic_i = 0 , 1 . (50)

Let Vt=(1âˆ’t)â¢f0+tâ¢f1subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ït=Ztâˆ’1â¢eâˆ’VtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡\rho_{t}=Z_{t}^{-1}e^{-V_{t}}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for Zt=âˆ«â„deâˆ’Vtâ¢dxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¥Z_{t}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x, and ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï as in Definition A.1. Then, ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï satisfies the partial Poincare inequality (PPI), i.e., there exists C>0ğ¶0C>0italic_C > 0 such that for all Ï•âˆˆğ’³01italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\phi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_Ï• âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT it holds

âˆ«[0,1]Ã—â„dÏ•2â¢dğ†â‰¤Câ¢âˆ«[0,1]Ã—â„dâ€–âˆ‡xÏ•â€–2â¢dğ†.subscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ï•2differential-dğ†ğ¶subscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥italic-Ï•2differential-dğ†\displaystyle\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{% \rho}\leq C\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}\phi\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}% \boldsymbol{\rho}.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_Ï â‰¤ italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_Ï . (51)
Proof.

Remark A.11.

(i) Gaussian distributions given by fi:=12â¢Ïƒ2â¢â€–xâˆ’mâ€–2assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–12superscriptğœ2superscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘š2f_{i}:=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|x-m\|^{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_m âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfy the assumptions of Proposition A.10.
(ii) In Proposition A.10, the regularity assumptions on the end points, i.e., f0,f1âˆˆC2â¢(â„d)subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1superscriptğ¶2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f_{0},f_{1}\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) can be relaxed. It is enough to assume that there exist sequences of functions (f0,n),(f1,n)âŠ‚C2â¢(â„d)subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘›superscriptğ¶2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘(f_{0,n}),(f_{1,n})\subset C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŠ‚ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which converge pointwise to f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, such that the assumptions of Proposition A.10 are satisfied uniformly in nğ‘›nitalic_n and such that â€–âˆ‡xVnâ€–Lâˆ,â€–Vnâ€–Lâˆsubscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›superscriptğ¿subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›superscriptğ¿\|\nabla_{x}V_{n}\|_{L^{\infty}},\|V_{n}\|_{L^{\infty}}âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are bounded in nğ‘›nitalic_n.
Hereby, also the Fisher-Rao curve given by linear interpolation of f0:=â€–xâ€–assignsubscriptğ‘“0normğ‘¥f_{0}:=\|x\|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ and f1:=minâ¡{â€–xâ€–,â€–xâˆ’mâ€–}assignsubscriptğ‘“1normğ‘¥normğ‘¥ğ‘šf_{1}:=\min\{\|x\|,\|x-m\|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ , âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_m âˆ¥ } with mâˆˆâ„dğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘m\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., the interpolation between two Laplacian (type) distributions, satisfies (PPI).

A.3 Existence of a solution to the Poisson Equation

Now, we consider the Poisson equation (34) in a slightly more abstract manner: Showing that a given Fisher-Rao flow ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve requires solving the following (family of) PDEs

âˆ’âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢âˆ‡st)=(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢Ït,tâˆˆ[0,1],formulae-sequenceâ‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¡01\displaystyle-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}\right)=\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1],- âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] , (52)

for the vector field vt=âˆ‡stsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying a suitable integrability condition. Here, Î±âˆˆL2â¢(ğ†)ğ›¼subscriptğ¿2ğ†\alpha\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_Î± âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ), Î±tâ‰”Î±â¢(t,â‹…)â‰”subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡â‹…\alpha_{t}\coloneqq\alpha(t,\cdot)italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” italic_Î± ( italic_t , â‹… ) and Î±tÂ¯â‰”ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[Î±t]â‰”Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\overline{\alpha_{t}}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\alpha_{t}]overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are given.

In order to do that, we look to find a weak solution to (52) in the space ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition A.12.

An element Ï•âˆˆğ’³01italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\phi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_Ï• âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a weak solution to (52) if it satisfies,

âˆ«01âˆ«â„dâŸ¨âˆ‡Ï•t,âˆ‡ÏˆtâŸ©â¢dÏtâ¢dt=âˆ«01âˆ«â„dÏˆtâ¢(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢dÏtâ¢dt,âˆ€Ïˆâˆˆğ’³01.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘âˆ‡subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡for-allğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\langle\nabla\phi_{t},\nabla\psi% _{t}\rangle\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}% \psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}% \mathrm{d}t,\quad\forall\psi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ‡ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t , âˆ€ italic_Ïˆ âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (53)

Note that for ÏˆâˆˆCcâˆâ¢((0,1)Ã—â„d)ğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\psi\in C_{c}^{\infty}((0,1)\times\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_Ïˆ âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( 0 , 1 ) Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) it holds for gâ¢(t)â‰”ğ”¼Ïtâ¢[Ïˆâ¢(t,â‹…)]â‰”ğ‘”ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ‘¡delimited-[]ğœ“ğ‘¡â‹…g(t)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\psi(t,\cdot)]italic_g ( italic_t ) â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , â‹… ) ] that Ïˆâˆ’gâˆˆğ’³01ğœ“ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\psi-g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_Ïˆ - italic_g âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since âˆ‡x(g)=0=âˆ«01âˆ«â„dgâ¢(t)â¢(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢dÏtâ¢dtsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘”0superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\nabla_{x}(g)=0=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g(t)(\alpha_{t}-\overline{% \alpha_{t}})\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}tâˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = 0 = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_t ) ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t, we have that (53) is also fulfilled for all ÏˆâˆˆCcâˆâ¢((0,1)Ã—â„d)ğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\psi\in C_{c}^{\infty}((0,1)\times\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_Ïˆ âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( 0 , 1 ) Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We can now prove Theorem 1 from Section 2.2, which provides a solution to the Poisson problem (52) globally in time tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

Theorem A.13.

Assume that ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï from Definition A.1 satisfies (PPI) for some K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0, and that 1ğ›’âˆˆL1,locâ¢([0,1]Ã—â„d)1ğ›’subscriptğ¿1loc01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_Ï end_ARG âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Furthermore, assume that Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯âˆˆL2â¢(ğ›’)subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2ğ›’\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ), i.e., â€–Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯â€–L2â¢(ğ›’)2â‰¤C<âˆsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2ğ›’2ğ¶\|\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\|_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}^{2}\leq C<\inftyâˆ¥ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Ï ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_C < âˆ. Then, there exists a unique weak solution sâˆˆğ’³01ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ’³01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to (52). Moreover, sğ‘ sitalic_s satisfies the following inequality

âˆ«01âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡sâ€–2â¢dÏtâ¢dtâ‰¤Kâ¢âˆ«01âˆ«â„d(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)2â¢dÏtâ¢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘ 2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla s\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho% _{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_s âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t â‰¤ italic_K âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . (54)
Proof.

Let A:ğ’³01â†’â„:ğ´â†’superscriptsubscriptğ’³01â„A:{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}\to\mathbb{R}italic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R be defined as

Aâ¢Ïˆ:=âˆ«01âˆ«â„dÏˆtâ¢(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢dÏtâ¢dt.assignğ´ğœ“superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle A\psi:=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}% -\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.italic_A italic_Ïˆ := âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t .

Therefore, we can rewrite our system of PDEs (52) as

âŸ¨s,ÏˆâŸ©ğ’³01=Aâ¢Ïˆ,âˆ€Ïˆâˆˆğ’³01.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ ğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ’³01ğ´ğœ“for-allğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ’³01\displaystyle\langle s,\psi\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}=A\psi,\quad\forall% \psi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}.âŸ¨ italic_s , italic_Ïˆ âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_A italic_Ïˆ , âˆ€ italic_Ïˆ âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (55)

Clearly, Ağ´Aitalic_A is a linear operator. Since ğ†ğ†\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï satisfies (PPI) the following holds:

|Aâ¢Ïˆ|2superscriptğ´ğœ“2\displaystyle\left|A\psi\right|^{2}| italic_A italic_Ïˆ | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =|âˆ«01âˆ«â„dÏˆtâ¢(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢dÏtâ¢dt|2=|âˆ«[0,1]Ã—â„dÏˆtâ¢(x)â¢(Î±tâ¢(x)âˆ’Î±tÂ¯â¢(x))â¢dğ†â¢(t,x)|2absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡2superscriptsubscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘¥subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ‘¥Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ‘¥differential-dğ†ğ‘¡ğ‘¥2\displaystyle=\left|\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\right|^{2}=\left|% \int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}(x)\left(\alpha_{t}(x)-\overline{% \alpha_{t}}(x)\right)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}(t,x)\right|^{2}= | âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = | âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_x ) ) roman_d bold_italic_Ï ( italic_t , italic_x ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¤(âˆ«(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)2â¢dğ†)â‹…(âˆ«|Ïˆt|2â¢dğ†)â‰¤Câ¢âˆ«01âˆ«â„d|Ïˆt|2â¢dÏtâ¢dtabsentâ‹…superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡2differential-dğ†superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡2differential-dğ†ğ¶superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle\leq\Big{(}\int\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}% \,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}\Big{)}\cdot\Big{(}\int|\psi_{t}|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}% \boldsymbol{\rho}\Big{)}\leq C\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|\psi_{t}|^{2}% \,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}tâ‰¤ ( âˆ« ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_Ï ) â‹… ( âˆ« | italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_Ï ) â‰¤ italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t

By Lemma A.8, the space ğ’³01superscriptsubscriptğ’³01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a Hilbert space. Remark A.14.

Note that in the case of Fisher-Rao flows, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± satisfies

âˆ‚tÏt=(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢Ït,tâˆˆ[0,1].formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¡01\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right% )\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1].âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] .

Lemma A.15.

Let ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï be such that ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded (from above) for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]. Then, for sâˆˆğ’³01ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ’³01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that âˆ‡stâˆˆTÏtâ¢ğ’«2â¢(â„d)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\nabla s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

Proof.

For a.e. tğ‘¡titalic_t, since ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded from above by assumption, Ccâˆâ¢(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is dense in H1â¢(Ït)superscriptğ»1subscriptğœŒğ‘¡H^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Now, stâˆˆH1â¢(Ït)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ»1subscriptğœŒğ‘¡s_{t}\in H^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) immediately yields the claim âˆ‡stâˆˆTÏtâ¢ğ’«2â¢(â„d)={âˆ‡Ï•:Ï•âˆˆCcâˆâ¢(â„d)}Â¯L2â¢(Ït)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptÂ¯conditional-setâˆ‡italic-Ï•italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\nabla s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})=\overline{\{\nabla% \phi:\phi\in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\}}^{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = overÂ¯ start_ARG { âˆ‡ italic_Ï• : italic_Ï• âˆˆ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. âˆ

It follows the proof of Theorem 2 from Section 2.2, which says that certain Fisher-Rao curves are indeed also Wasserstein absolutely continuous curves.

Theorem A.16.

Let Ï0,Ï1subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{0},\rho_{1}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be probability densities on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and assume that ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Fisher-Rao curve defined by

âˆ‚tÏt=(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢Ït,subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}})\rho_{t},âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

such that ğ›’ğ›’\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_Ï and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± satisfy the assumptions of Theorem A.13.

Then, ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve with vector field âˆ‡xssubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ \nabla_{x}sâˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s, where sâˆˆğ’³01ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ’³01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unique weak solution of (53). If ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded for a.e. tğ‘¡titalic_t, we have that âˆ‡xstâˆˆTÏtâ¢ğ’«2â¢(â„d)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\nabla_{x}s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], i.e., for every other vector field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying the continuity equation for ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have that â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)â‰¥â€–âˆ‡xstâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}\geq\|\nabla_{x}s_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

Furthermore, it holds that

âˆ«01âˆ«â„dâ€–âˆ‡xstâ€–2â¢dÏtâ¢dtâ‰¤Kâ¢âˆ«01âˆ«â„d(Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)2â¢dÏtâ¢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡2differential-dsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡differential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}s_{t}\|^{2}\,\mathrm% {d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t â‰¤ italic_K âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . (56)

Note that by the Benamou-Brenier formula, see (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Equation 8.0.3), the left-hand side of (56) is an upper bound for the Wasserstein distance W22â¢(Ï0,Ï1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š22subscriptğœŒ0subscriptğœŒ1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the double-integral on the right-hand side defines the Fisher-Rao action ğ’œFRsubscriptğ’œFR\mathcal{A}_{\rm FR}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_FR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Using (Î±tâˆ’Î±tÂ¯)â¢Ït=âˆ‚tÏtsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡Â¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}})\rho_{t}=\partial_{t}\rho_{t}( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Theorem A.13, we can conclude that ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the continuity equation

âˆ‚tÏt+âˆ‡â‹…(Ïtâ¢vt)=0subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…âˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡0\partial_{t}\rho_{t}+\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}v_{t})=0âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ‡ â‹… ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 (57)

with a Borel vector field vtâ‰”âˆ‡stâ‰”subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the sense of distributions. Let us apply the above result to the curve given by linear interpolation of the energy functions f0,f1subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Corollary A.17.

Proof.

again, with a constant C>0ğ¶0C>0italic_C > 0 not depending tğ‘¡titalic_t. Remark A.18.

Hence, the Fisher-Rao curves defined by linear interpolation Vt=(1âˆ’t)â¢f0+tâ¢f1subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein sense, e.g., in the cases (see also Remark A.11)

  • â€¢

    Gaussian distributions given by fi:=12â¢Ïƒ2â¢â€–xâˆ’mâ€–2assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–12superscriptğœ2superscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘š2f_{i}:=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|x-m\|^{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_m âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    Laplacian distributions given by fi:=1Ïƒâ¢â€–xâˆ’mâ€–assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–1ğœnormğ‘¥ğ‘šf_{i}:=\frac{1}{\sigma}\|x-m\|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_m âˆ¥,

  • â€¢

    Laplacian type distributions given by fi:=minâ¡{â€–xâ€–,â€–xâˆ’mâ€–}assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–normğ‘¥normğ‘¥ğ‘šf_{i}:=\min\{\|x\|,\|x-m\|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ , âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_m âˆ¥ }.

A.4 A teleportation issue with the linear interpolation

In this section we want to demonstrate that the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the (optimal) velocity field (5) belonging to the Fisher-Rao path given by linear interpolation ft:=(1âˆ’t)â¢f0+tâ¢f1assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“1f_{t}:=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, explodes for times tğ‘¡titalic_t close to 1111, when the measures Ï0subscriptğœŒ0\rho_{0}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï1subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{1}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are asymmetrical to each other.

In the following, we restrict ourselves to the one-dimensional setting â„1superscriptâ„1\mathbb{R}^{1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in order to exploit the isometry from the Wasserstein space ğ’«2â¢(â„1)subscriptğ’«2superscriptâ„1\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{1})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) into the convex cone ğ’âŠ‚L2â¢(0,1)ğ’subscriptğ¿201\mathcal{C}\subset L_{2}(0,1)caligraphic_C âŠ‚ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 1 ) of quantile functions, also see (Duong etÂ al., 2024, Section 3). For the sake of self-containedness, we give a short introduction of the necessary tools: For Î¼âˆˆğ’«2â¢(â„)ğœ‡subscriptğ’«2â„\mu\in\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R})italic_Î¼ âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R ) we define its cumulative distribution function (CDF) by

FÎ¼â¢(x):=Î¼â¢(âˆ’âˆ,x],xâˆˆâ„,formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptğ¹ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥â„F_{\mu}(x):=\mu(-\infty,x],\quad x\in\mathbb{R},italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := italic_Î¼ ( - âˆ , italic_x ] , italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R , (66)

and its left-continuous quantile function

QÎ¼â¢(s):=minâ¡{xâˆˆâ„:Fâ¢(x)â‰¥s},sâˆˆ(0,1).formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptğ‘„ğœ‡ğ‘ :ğ‘¥â„ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘ 01Q_{\mu}(s):=\min\{x\in\mathbb{R}:F(x)\geq s\},\quad s\in(0,1).italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) := roman_min { italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R : italic_F ( italic_x ) â‰¥ italic_s } , italic_s âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) . (67)

Then, it holds the isometric property

W22â¢(Î¼,Î½)=âˆ«01|QÎ¼â¢(s)âˆ’QÎ½â¢(s)|2â¢dsfor allÂ â¢Î¼,Î½âˆˆğ’«2â¢(â„).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Š22ğœ‡ğœˆsuperscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğœ‡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘„ğœˆğ‘ 2differential-dğ‘ for allÂ ğœ‡ğœˆsubscriptğ’«2â„W_{2}^{2}(\mu,\nu)=\int_{0}^{1}|Q_{\mu}(s)-Q_{\nu}(s)|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}s\quad% \text{for all }\mu,\nu\in\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}).italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ , italic_Î½ ) = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_s for all italic_Î¼ , italic_Î½ âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R ) . (68)

Now, by (Ambrosio etÂ al., 2005, Theorem 8.3.1), the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal field vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belonging to an absolutely continuous Wasserstein curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be characterized by the metric derivative of the curve via

â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)=|Ïâ€²â¢(t)|:=limsâ†’tW2â¢(Ït,Ïs)|tâˆ’s|for a.e.Â â¢tâˆˆ[0,1].formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğœŒâ€²ğ‘¡assignsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Š2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ for a.e.Â ğ‘¡01\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}=|\rho^{\prime}(t)|:=\lim_{s\to t}\frac{W_{2}(\rho_% {t},\rho_{s})}{|t-s|}\quad\text{for a.e. }t\in[0,1].âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) | := roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s â†’ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_t - italic_s | end_ARG for a.e. italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] . Using the aforementioned isometry (68) and Komuraâ€™s theorem, it holds for a.e. tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]

Hence, if we can explicitly compute the quantiles QÏtsubscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (and its time derivative), we get an analytic representation of â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via

In order to do so, we choose the prior and target measures the following way: Let f0â¢(x):=|x|assignsubscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¥ğ‘¥f_{0}(x):=|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := | italic_x | and f1â¢(x):=2â¢minâ¡{|x|,|xâˆ’m|}assignsubscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥2ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘šf_{1}(x):=2\min\{|x|,|x-m|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := 2 roman_min { | italic_x | , | italic_x - italic_m | }, where the second mode m>0ğ‘š0m>0italic_m > 0 is fixed for the moment. By Corollary A.17 and Remark A.18, the Fisher-Rao curve ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by linear interpolation of f0,f1subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘“1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Wasserstein absolutely continuous. Ïtâˆeâˆ’|xâ¢|âˆ’t|â¢xâˆ’mâ¢|+t|â¢|x|âˆ’|xâˆ’m||for allÂ â¢xâˆˆâ„,tâˆˆ[0,1],formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptğœŒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘šformulae-sequencefor allÂ ğ‘¥â„ğ‘¡01\rho_{t}\propto e^{-|x|-t|x-m|+t||x|-|x-m||}\quad\text{for all }x\in\mathbb{R}% ,~{}t\in[0,1],italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | italic_x | - italic_t | italic_x - italic_m | + italic_t | | italic_x | - | italic_x - italic_m | | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R , italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] , (72)

up to a normalization constant Ztsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡Z_{t}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which we calculate below.

Calculating the CDF of ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Ztâ‹…FÏtâ¢(x)=21+tâˆ’(11+t+1âˆ’1+3â¢t)â¢eâˆ’m2â¢(1+t)+1âˆ’1+3â¢tâ¢exâ¢(âˆ’1+3â¢t)âˆ’2â¢tâ¢m,m2â‰¤xâ‰¤m,formulae-sequenceâ‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¥21ğ‘¡11ğ‘¡113ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘š21ğ‘¡113ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥13ğ‘¡2ğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘š2ğ‘¥ğ‘šZ_{t}\cdot F_{\rho_{t}}(x)~{}=~{}\frac{2}{1+t}-\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-% 1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-\frac{m}{2}(1+t)}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}e^{x(-1+3t)-2tm},\quad\frac{m% }{2}\leq x\leq m,italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x ( - 1 + 3 italic_t ) - 2 italic_t italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‰¤ italic_x â‰¤ italic_m , (75)
Ztâ‹…FÏtâ¢(x)=â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘¥absent\displaystyle Z_{t}\cdot F_{\rho_{t}}(x)~{}=~{}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = 21+tâˆ’(11+t+1âˆ’1+3â¢t)â¢eâˆ’m2â¢(1+t)21ğ‘¡11ğ‘¡113ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘š21ğ‘¡\displaystyle\frac{2}{1+t}-\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-% \frac{m}{2}(1+t)}divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (76)

where the normalization constant is hence given by

Zt=Ztâ‹…FÏtâ¢(âˆ)=subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹subscriptğœŒğ‘¡absent\displaystyle Z_{t}=Z_{t}\cdot F_{\rho_{t}}(\infty)~{}=~{}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âˆ ) = 21+tâˆ’(11+t+1âˆ’1+3â¢t)â¢eâˆ’m2â¢(1+t)21ğ‘¡11ğ‘¡113ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘š21ğ‘¡\displaystyle\frac{2}{1+t}-\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-% \frac{m}{2}(1+t)}divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (78)
+\displaystyle++ (11+t+1âˆ’1+3â¢t)â¢eâˆ’mâ¢(1âˆ’t).11ğ‘¡113ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ‘š1ğ‘¡\displaystyle\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-m(1-t)}.( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m ( 1 - italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (79)

Calculating the quantile function of ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Since FÏtâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ¹subscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…F_{\rho_{t}}(\cdot)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) is continuous and strictly increasing, its inverse is given by FÏtâˆ’1=QÏtsuperscriptsubscriptğ¹subscriptğœŒğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡F_{\rho_{t}}^{-1}=Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A simple calculation now yields

QÏtâ¢(s)=11+tâ¢lnâ¡(Ztâ¢(1+t)â¢s),0<sâ‰¤s1,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡ğ‘ 11ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡ğ‘ 0ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ 1Q_{\rho_{t}}(s)~{}=~{}\frac{1}{1+t}\ln\big{(}Z_{t}(1+t)s\big{)},\quad 0<s\leq s% _{1},italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG roman_ln ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_t ) italic_s ) , 0 < italic_s â‰¤ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (80)

Here, the subintervals are given by
