Calculating the time derivative âˆ‚tQÏtsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\partial_{t}Q_{\rho_{t}}âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Using standard differentiation rules, the time derivative of QÏtsubscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed separately on each subinterval (si,si+1)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1(s_{i},s_{i+1})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Since the resulting derivatives become unbearably long, we only include them in the Supplementary Material. Nevertheless, they can be computed analytically as elementary functions, and be inserted into the desired integral (71). By numerical integration, we can finally approximate the norm â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT arbitrarily close. The computed results are depicted in Figure 2 for different values of the mode m>0ğ‘š0m>0italic_m > 0; roughly speaking, for late times tâˆ¼1similar-toğ‘¡1t\sim 1italic_t âˆ¼ 1, the norm of the velocity field grows exponentially with mğ‘šmitalic_m.

On a side note, the integration of âˆ‚tQÏtsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘„subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\partial_{t}Q_{\rho_{t}}âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only on the subintervals (s1,s2)subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2(s_{1},s_{2})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (s2,s3)subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 3(s_{2},s_{3})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) contributes to the explosion of â€–vtâ€–L2â¢(Ït)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿2subscriptğœŒğ‘¡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Intuitively, this corresponds to the fact that mass gets shifted very abruptly mainly in the areas xâˆˆ(0,m2)ğ‘¥0ğ‘š2x\in(0,\frac{m}{2})italic_x âˆˆ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) and (m2,m)ğ‘š2ğ‘š(\frac{m}{2},m)( divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_m ) for late times tğ‘¡titalic_t.

A.5 Additional Details on the Experiments

Implementation and evaluation details.

We implement the algorithms in Pytorch Paszke etÂ al. (2019). For both experiments we use standard MLPs with â€swishâ€ activation functions. For the linear and learned interpolations we parameterize the vector fields directly. The learned interpolation also uses the same network for Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ. The linear interpolation uses the same network for the time dependent function Ctsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the learned and gradient flow interpolations we implement Ctsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the same network with less parameters. The gradient flow interpolation also uses a smaller network for the time scheduling function gğ‘”gitalic_g as defined in Section 4. In case of normalized energy functions we can omit the parametrization of Ctsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the learned and gradient flow interpolations. We simulate the corresponding ODEs using the torchdiffeq Chen (2018) package with the Runge-Kutta adaptive step size solver (â€dopri5â€). For the linear and learned interpolation we use 50505050 time steps along which the loss is computed and the gradients are accumulated with a batch size of 256256256256. For the gradient flow interpolation we sample 4096409640964096 particles at random uniform time points and therefore do not accumulate gradients. For the GMM example we train the linear and learned interpolations for 5âˆ—1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 âˆ— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations. For the many well example we train the linear interpolation for 5âˆ—1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 âˆ— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the learned for 4âˆ—1044superscript1044*10^{4}4 âˆ— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations. The gradient flow interpolation is trained for 4âˆ—1054superscript1054*10^{5}4 âˆ— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations in both experiments.
We compute log weights of the generated samples by using the continuous change of variables formula and the corresponding implementation from Chen (2018). We evaluate the methods by generating 5âˆ—1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 âˆ— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples and log weight and computing the effective sample size, negative log likelihood and energy distance. We report mean and standard deviation over 10101010 evaluation runs. The effective sample size is computed as in Midgley etÂ al. (2023). We compute the energy distance using the GeomLoss library Feydy etÂ al. (2019). For the target energy functions and plotting utilities we use the code provided in Midgley etÂ al. (2023).

The gradient flow interpolation faced some difficulty in the many well experiment when, while sampling, particles entered regions of very low density. This could severely affect sampling times when using the adaptive step size solver. Therefore we used an Euler scheme and resampled a given batch if a NaN error is raised. This happens approximately for 0.01%percent0.010.01\%0.01 % of the particles.

Choice of latent distribution.

The linear and learned interpolations depend significantly on the choice of initial distribution. In the following we visualize and compare numerically the results when starting in Gaussians with different standard deviations. Note that when using a small standard deviation not all modes are recovered. On the other hand choosing a very large standard deviation leads to the modes close to 00 not receiving enough mass.
